head.title: The Auld Fiddle. A poem occasioned by a person's treading on it and crushing it to pieces.11 First published in Poetical Essays, (1788), pp. 202-204; reprinted as “Elegy on My Auld Fiddle” in Charleston Courier [Charleston, SC] (March 25, 1807) and in Port Folio [Philadelphia], 6 (August 20, 1808): 127-128. The Port Folio, one of the more prestigious American magazines of the period, was published by Bradford and Inskeep, for whom Turnbull’s Scottish friend, the poet and ornithologist, Alexander Wilson worked as an editor from 1806 till 1813. Earlier, in 1807, the same magazine had published another Turnbull poem, “Ode to Suspicion.”

lg.l: We see that each revolving day,
The rarest earthly things decay;
Nor can our best inventions save
Them frae the universal grave:
Still some disaster, unforeseen,
Maks them as they had never been.
See my auld Fiddle, ance sae good,
Which pat me aft in merry mood
When a’ things fail’d; see, in disguise,
In broken fragments where she lies,
Thrawn in a neuk22 n. corner, recess. wi’ ither lumber,
Nae mair my study to encumber;
Of brig and finger-brod bereft,
Nae string, nor bass, nor tenor left;
Her hand broke aff, her wame33 n. womb. shot in,
And for to tune her ne’er a pin;
Her back and sides in waefu’ case,
Sad monuments of her disgrace.
Nae mair, alas! on her I’ll play
Piano sweet, or blithe Strathspey;44 Traditional Scottish dance tune in 4/4 time, e.g., “The Bonnie Banks O’ Loch Lomond” or “Auld Lang Syne”.
Nae mair, when dowie thoughts invade,
Shall she be summon’d to my aid:
Like some auld trophy she may hing,
A dismal melancholy thing.
What tho’ she was of beauteous frame,
And frae the far Cremona55 City in northern Italy known for its musical history and traditions. came,
Yet that, and a’ her tones sae sweet,
Cou’d not award the murd’rer’s feet,
Wha, heedless what he heard or saw,
Crush’d her poor banes against the wa’;
A mournfu’ echo, sad and sweet,
Resounded wi’ his clumsy feet:
Sae Poets tell before she die,
The swan sings her own elegy.
May minstrels a’ the villain hate,
And mock and jeer him air and late;
May his dull lugs66 n. ears. be ever found,
Deaf to the harmony of sound;
May discord deave him night and day,
While my auld Fiddle, tho’s she’s lame,
Is sounded by the voice of fame.
Ye wand’ring spirits of the wind,
May ye my silent Fiddle find,
And, as ye tak your nightly rounds,
Recal, as erst, enchanting sounds.

Methinks I hear M‘Pherson88 Perhaps James MacPherson (1675-1700), for whom the fiddle tune “MacPherson’s Rant” is named, who before his execution as an outlaw was reputed to have broken his own fiddle on the scaffold. there,
Awake some Caledonian99 Scottish; from Caledonia: literary name and Latin term for Scotland. air,
Or Handel,1010 George Frederick Handel (1685-1759); German-born British composer. master o’ the band,
Employ his sound-compelling hand:
Haste, haste, ye tunefu’ shapes of air,
And to my ruin’d strings repair.
